section.name: description
section.description:
The "hco" utility helps manage user credentials. It provides basic operations for adding users, removing users, managing passwords for HTTP Basic Authentication support, as well as key commands to help manage API keys for direct Bearer authentication support via HCLI Core API Key (HCOAK).

The expected HCOAK HTTP Authentication Bearer format is simply base64 encoded and colon separated 'keyid:hcoak' (i.e. Bearer base64(keyid:hcoak)). For example:

keyid = GJSLKO5Z5M

hcoak = hcoak_FMn4dirl8kVoV1z96II84AeEDIbYyxTXZkMLllfgx8Deqwz0D1Rq88ObQBleUpN_Qncek8otlPx4ZaIYWtFWcQ

base64(GJSLKO5Z5M:hcoak_FMn4dirl8kVoV1z96II84AeEDIbYyxTXZkMLllfgx8Deqwz0D1Rq88ObQBleUpN_Qncek8otlPx4ZaIYWtFWcQ)

section.name: examples
section.description:
hco useradd johndoe

tr -d '\(rsn' < somepasswordfile | hco passwd username

hco userdel johndoe

hco ls

hco key johndoe

hco key rotate GJSLKO5Z5M

section.name: name
section.description: useradd - create a new user account

section.name: description
section.description: Creates a new user account with the specified username. The account will be created with a locked password; use passwd to set the password.

section.name: description
section.description: Deletes a user account and all associated resources.

section.name: description
section.description: Changes the password of the specified user account. The password must be provided via stdin for security. Note that the HCLI client used to interact with hco (e.g. huckle) must have credentials set for a valid user. A user can manage their own credentials but the admin user can manage any users.

section.name: description
section.description: List all users in the credentials file.

section.name: description
section.description: Creates a new HCLI Core API Key (HCOAK) for the specified username. A user can create their own API keys but the admin can create API keys for any user. The command returns a unique keyid followed by the API key and the creation timestamp when successful.

command.name: rm
command.description: Remove an API key by keyid.

command.name: rotate
command.description: Rotate an API key by keyid.

section.name: name
section.description: rm - remove an API key by keyid

section.name: description
section.description: Removes a API key by keyid if the requester owns the API key or if the requester is the administrator.

section.name: name
section.description: rotate - rotate an API key by keyid

section.name: description
section.description: Rotates a API key by keyid if the requester owns the API key or if the requester is the administrator. The command returns the same keyid, followed by a new API key and creation timestamp, when successful

section.name: description
section.description: Lists all API keys the requester owns or all keys if the requester is the administrator.

section.name: description
section.description: Validates provided credentials. Supports basic auth (username/password) and HCOAK validation. This is intended to be used to check the validity of provided credentials. The password or apikey must be provided via stdin for security. Note that the HCLI client used to interact with hco (e.g. huckle) must have credentials set for a valid user or apikey to be able to validate provided credentials.

command.name: hcoak
command.description: Validate HCLI Core API Key (HCOAK) credentials

section.name: name
section.description: validate - validate HTTP Basic Authentication credentials

section.name: description
section.description: Validates provided credentials. Supports HTTP Basic Authentication (username/password). This is intended to be used to check the validity of provided credentials. The password is provided via stdin for security. Note that the HCLI client used to interact with hco (e.g. huckle) must have credentials set for a valid user or apikey to be able to validate provided credentials.

section.name: name
section.description: validate - validate HCLI Core API Key (HCOAK) Authentication credentials

section.name: description
section.description: Validates provided credentials. Supports HCLI Core API Key (HCOAK) authentication (keyid/apikey). This is intended to be used to check the validity of provided credentials. The apikey is provided via stdin for security. Note that the HCLI client used to interact with hco (e.g. huckle) must have credentials set for a valid user or apikey to be able to validate provided credentials.
